newsitem.title: KAZAKHSTAN: Kazakhs still face most painful market reforms - PM.
newsitem.headline: Kazakhs still face most painful market reforms - PM.

text.p: Kazakhstan's embattled prime minister has said in a rare interview that his former Soviet republic has still to pull itself through the most painful stage of market reform.
"I think we will pass through the most painful step in 1997 and the first half of 1998," Kazakh Prime Minister Akezhan Kazhegeldin told the weekly Karavan newspaper published at the weekend.
Patience with reform is at a low ebb among the 16.9 million population, tired of having to go for months without their wages and pensions. Many Soviet-era factories are at a standstill.

Kazakh President Nursultan Nazarbayev, alarmed at the dent the payments crisis has made on his flagging popularity, sought in Kazhegeldin a lightning rod for the discontent, threatening in March to sack him unless he found a way to pay off debts.
Kazhegeldin, 45 and a former businessman, said he had been prepared to resign if Nazarbayev disagreed with his reform programme. "I used this as a means of giving the president a choice," he said.
But the president had second thoughts last month, giving Kazhegeldin until the end of the year to pay off state debts to pensioners.
The prime minister was also sanguine in the face of the government's widespread unpopularity.
"I understand perfectly that popularity won't come to us," he said, adding: "I am not ashamed of what I have done in the last three years."

Investors in the republic, a mountainous area the size of western Europe boasting huge reserves of oil and gas, breathed a collective sigh of relief over Kazhegeldin's survival. They see him as the guarantor of reform.
Kazhegeldin has won admiration for slashing inflation to around 30 percent in 1996 -- inflation is targetted at 15-17 percent this year -- and for pushing forward an ambitious sale of state assets.

"Kazhegeldin was weak, he had a lot of problems earlier this year, but he's dealt with these and come out on top," said a Western diplomat based in the Kazakh capital Almaty. "He's got plenty of enemies but he's in better shape," he said.
Pyotr Svoik, head of the opposition grouping Azamat, or "Citizen", and a relentless critic of Kazhegeldin, said: "He remains a powerful figure."

Neither do investors appear to worry much over Kazhegeldin's defeat at the hands of the country's powerful "oil barons", who dug in their heels over his fast-paced privatisation of the oil and gas industry. He lost control of the sector in a government shake-up in March.
"The feeling in the market is that he (Kazhegeldin) is in control," said an Almaty-based market analyst. "The loss of the oil is a minor setback," he said.

However Nazarbayev, worried about what he has called a potentially "dangerous divide between rich and poor", is keeping a close eye on Kazhelgeldin, whose political fortunes are now tied closely to his ability to deliver on the payments crisis.
